(January - November 2010) |notes=*Hizbul Islam was disbanded and merged into al-Shabaab on December 20, 2010. }} {{Campaignbox War in Somalia (2009â)}} The '''Battle of Mogadishu (2010â2011)''' began on August 23, 2010 when [[al-Shabaab]] insurgents began attacking government and [[African Union Mission to Somalia]] (AMISOM) positions in the Somali capital. Al-Shabaab began its offensive after its spokesman said the group was declaring a "massive war" on the AMISOM force, describing its 6,000 "peacekeepers" as "invaders".{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-11068805 |title=BBC News - Somali MPs killed in hotel suicide attack |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= August 24, 2010|accessdate=2010-08-24}} In December 2010 the number of [[AMISOM]] troops was increased to 8,000 and later to 9,000. ==Background== Al-Shabaab had previously declared a "massive" war against the internationally backed Transitional Federal Government and [[AMISOM]] troop "invaders." On July 11, 2010 they [[July 2010 Kampala attacks|attacked]] [[Kampala]], Uganda in revenge for the country's support of [[African Union]] troops in Somalia. The attacks took place as hundreds of additional Ugandan troops arrived in the country.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/08/201082464449278785.html |title=Al-Shabab vows 'massive' Somali war - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2008-12-19 |accessdate=2010-08-24}} == Fighting == ===2010=== ====August: Ramadan Offensive==== Forty people were reportedly killed and more than one hundred injured in the violence that began on August 23.{{cite web|url=http://www.france24.com/en/20100824-lawmakers-feared-dead-mogadishu-hotel-attack-somalia-shabaab |title=Somali lawmakers killed in Mogadishu hotel raid |publisher=France24 |date= |accessdate=2010-08-24}} After that fighting continued and the next day when several al-Shabaab militants, disguised as government workers, [[Muna hotel attack|launched an attack at the Muna Hotel]], a hotel known for hosting many Somali government officials and politicians, the hotel was located a kilometre away from the presidential palace [[Villa Somalia]]. Thirty one people were reported killed in the hotel incident, including eleven lawmakers.{{cite web|url=http://www.alertnet.org/thenews/newsdesk/LDE67O078.htm |title=Reuters AlertNet - Al Shabaab push towards Somali president's palace |publisher=Alertnet.org |date= |accessdate=2010-08-27}} By August 26, one-hundred fifteen people had been killed and, two hundred had been woundedhttp://allafrica.com/stories/201008270008.html and hundreds of people were reported to have fled the city. Both sides claimed advances with Mujahideen fighters making new bases from the areas they had captured; however, a police spokesman denied al-Shabaab claims that government troops were losing territory in the city.{{cite web|url=http://www.globalpost.com/breaking-news/global/somalis-flee-fourth-day-violence-mogadishu |title=Somalis flee fourth day of violence in Mogadishu |publisher=GlobalPost |date= |accessdate=2010-08-27}} The next day, al-Shabaab said it had called eleven truckloads of reinforcements to take over the capital Mogadishu after a week-long battle. The government again, however, continued to deny claims that al-Shabaab was gaining any ground.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/africa/2010/08/20108279334991422.html |title=Somali fighters attack capital - Africa |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2010-08-27}} Eleven government troops were reported killed by al-Shabaab as well as five al-Shabaab fighters that day.{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/140217.html |title=PressTV - Violence kills 43 in Somali capital |publisher=Presstv.ir |date= |accessdate=2010-08-27}} On August 30, fighting was renewed when al-Shabaab fighters attempted to take a government barracks around Sigale in the capital's Hodan neighbourhood. The ensuring action left six confirmed dead and sixteen wounded {{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20100830/wl_africa_afp/somaliaunrest |title=Fresh Mogadishu clashes kill 6 |publisher=Yahoo|date= |accessdate=2010-08-30}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} and by the end of the month [[UPI]] reported that a mortar attack by al-Shabaab killed four Ugandan peacekeepers guarding the [[Villa Somalia|presidential palace]] in Mogadishu. A [[TFG]] spokesman. Barigye Ba-Hoku denied claims though by al-Shabaab that the group was close to capturing a road connecting the [[Villa Somalia|Palace]] to the [[Mogadishu International Airport|Airport]].{{cite web|url=http://www.upi.com/Top_News/International/2010/08/31/Attack-kills-UN-peacekeepers-in-Somalia/UPI-63521283258015/ |title=Attack kills U.N. peacekeepers in Somalia |publisher=UPI|date=2010-08-31 |accessdate=2010-09-05}} ====September==== The first week of September started with at least nineteen people being killed in fresh fighting between forces loyal to the Western-backed government of Somalia and al-Shabaab fighters in Mogadishu.http://www.aljazeerah.info/News/2010/September/2%20n/19%20Somalis%20Killed%20in%20Mogadishu%20Fighting,%20September%202,%202010.htm Almost 14,000 of the displaced people left Mogadishu by the fifth entirely as fighting continued,http://english.alshahid.net/archives/12329 and by weeks end three more Somalis are killed and twenty-three wounded as five hundred shells pounded northern and southern parts of the capital.http://www.postbulletin.com/newsmanager/templates/localnews_story.asp?z=50&a=468503 On September 9 al-Shabaab attacked Mogadishu's [[Aden Adde International Airport|airport]] when a bomb exploded outside. A second vehicle full of militants then opened fire on the peacekeepers and Somali security forces that left at least eight people are killed (two of whom were peacekeeping force soldiers).http://www.voanews.com/english/news/africa/Somali-Witnesses-Say-Car-Bomb-Attack-on-Airport-Kills-8-102527189.html On September 16 at least eighteen civilians are killed in fighting between al-Shabaab and the African-backed government forces near the [[Bakaara Market]]http://www.ansa.it/ansalatina/notizie/rubriche/mundo/20100916200835144643.html fighting contuned into September 20 with at least 10 more civilian casualties.http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/10_people_killed_25_others_injured_fighting_in_Somalia.shtml On September 20, Islamic militants seized two radio stations in the capital,http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somali_insurgents_seized_Media_Stations_in_Mogadishu.shtml and suicide bomber blew herself up at the gates of the presidential palace in Mogadishu, slightly injuring two soldiers.http://www.france24.com/fr/20100920-somalie-kamikaze-presidence-mogadiscio-attaque-explosion-suspecte-shebab-perimetre Al-Shabaab launched a new offensive against government forces and AMISOM on September 22. Nineteen civilians and twenty-four Islamists were killed, one soldier member of AMISOM was killed and two others wounded as a result.http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jmjaB7D0AkKWP5F0di4LyQ-tal3Q On September 27 al-Shabaab militants attacked the National Parliament building with [[Mortar (weapon)|mortar]]s while a lawmakers meeting was assembled. Government soldiers and African Union forces repelled the attack however.http://www.ansa.it/ansalatina/notizie/fdg/201009271651386387/201009271651386387.html ====October==== Between October 5â6, at least fifteen people were killed and twenty-two others wounded in fighting in Mogadishu between insurgent forces and AMISOM. Most of the dead were civilians.http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Somalia_At_least_15_killed_in_renewed_Mogadishu_fighting.shtml On October 7 however it was reported that AU troops had captured more territory and were expected to control half of the city by the end of the month.http://allafrica.com/stories/201010080035.html By October 11â12, fifteen more people are killed in clashes as fighting contuned.http://www.ccun.org/News/2010/October/11%20n/18%20Somalis%20Killed%20in%20Mogadishu%20Fighting,%20October%2011-12,%202010.htm Organized by the city's local government on October 24, hundreds of people rallied in the Somali government controlled part of Mogadishu to protest against the Islamist insurgency and call for peaceful resolution.http://www.focus-fen.net/index.php?id=n233385 By the end of the month, officials in Mogadishu claimed that they had the upper hand in six of the capitalâs 16 districts as fighting continues. Outside the capital Ahlu Sunna wal Jamaa had also made additional progress chasing al-Shabaab out of a few towns in the recent weeks. Al-Shabaab however is reported to be continuing its terror tactics and smart guerrilla tactics.http://www.eastafricaforum.net/2010/10/30/battle-for-mogadishu-escalates/ ====November==== [[File:Mogadishu nov 26 01.png|thumb|300px|Mogadishu November 26, 2010]] On November 1, at least twelve people were killed in a battle between Government forces and militants. Three government soldiers were killed, with six wounded. Witnesses claim civilians were also killed during the battle.{{cite web|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5g7Slk7NocIlUUFzIZklnZeJ6r1iw?docId=CNG.809df977b92d0cf07c212de2205b6b72.e31|title=Mogadishu fighting kills 12|date=November 1, 2010|publisher=AFP|accessdate=2 November 2010}} The next day, Somalia's new [[Prime Minister of Somalia|prime minister]] [[Mohamed Abdullahi Mohamed]] is sworn in as twenty-one more people are killed and thirty wounded, as allied TFG and African Union forces battled al-Shabaab insurgents. Mohamed was quoted as saying "I will uphold and protect the laws of the country and I will pursue the common interest of the people and the nation.".http://www.garoweonline.com/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=374:somalias-new-prime-minister-farmajo-sworn-in-21-killed-in-mogadishu&catid=55:somalia&Itemid=79 By November 11, twelve more people were killed and twenty-five others injured after an attack in Mogadishu's northern district of Boondheere.http://www.siasat.com/english/news/12-die-battle-mogadishu and November 18 saw twenty-one more civilians killed from artillery shelling.http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1416387/Twenty-one-civilians-killed-in-Mogadishu On November 28, the president of [[Uganda]] [[Yoweri Museveni]] visited Mogadishu and urged the international community to provide more support for the government of Somalia.http://blogs.voanews.com/breaking-news/2010/11/28/ugandas-museveni-visits-mogadishu/ However the next day at least fifteen people died and twenty-five injured after Islamist fighters attacked government positions in the northern part of the city.http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-11-30/fighting-in-somalia-s-capital-leaves-at-least-15-people-dead-25-injured.html ====December==== The month began with more AMISOM troops being deployed on December 2 as more attacks continued, mostly in the northern part of the city.{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/somaliaNews/idAFLDE6B10JU20101202?sp=true | work=Reuters | title=AU deploys more troops to Somalia as fighting rages | date=December 2, 2010}} On December 5, at lease twelve more people and twenty others were wounded as a result of heavy artillery exchange in one of the city's northern districts.http://www.garoweonline.com/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=514:fighting-kills-dozen-in-mogadishu&catid=55:somalia&Itemid=79 Fifteen additional people were killed between the 10th and 11thhttp://www.garoweonline.com/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=532:15-killed-in-mogadishu-clashes-over-weekend&catid=55:somalia&Itemid=79 and on the 15th heavy fighting was reported as al-Shabaab tried to cut off Maka-Almukarama which is the only street in Mogadishu that the Somali government officials and the African Union troops use for their especial purposes.http://www.garoweonline.com/english/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=537:somalia-dawn-battle-erupts-in-mogadishu&catid=55:somalia&Itemid=79 Over 100 people were killed in the clashes.http://www.presstv.com/detail/153972.html On 20 December 2010, Hizbul Islam officially surrendered to al-Shabaab and the two organisations merged. As result al-Shabaab fighters started taking over Hizbul Islam positions,http://allafrica.com/stories/201012201376.html while Hizbul Islam fighters were allowed to enter al-Shabaab controlled territories as well.http://allafrica.com/stories/201012210370.html On December 23, the two sides formally declared unity in Mogadishu with a ceremony held in the Nasrudin mosque, which was attended by al-Shabaab's official spokesman [[Sheik Ali Mohamud Raghe]] and [[Sheik Abdifatah Mo'allin Mohamed]], Hizbul Islam's head of information. http://allafrica.com/stories/201012240039.html New fighting broke out on December 25 killing at least two and injuring at least 25, the fighting happened as al-Shabaab declared it would increase its attacks after its merger with Hizbul Islam.http://allafrica.com/stories/201012250011.html Twenty five more people were killed and thirty two civilians were wounded in the fighting on the 30th. http://www.siasat.com/english/news/clashes-kill-25-people-mogadishu ===2011=== ====January==== The new year opened up with a violent mutiny staged by government forces which resulted in three soldiers being killed and seven wounded over nonpayment of salary. Nineteen people were also killed in clashes on January 1 as insurgents attacked bases of Somali government forces.http://allafrica.com/stories/201101020005.html ====February - March: anti-insurgency offensive==== On February 19th [[AMISOM]] forces clashed with [[al-Shabaab]] in the Sigaale and El Hindi areas of Hawl Wadag distric. It lasted for two days, reaching with a death toll of more than 20 people including several foreigner [[al-Shabaab]] fighters.http://www.ansa.it/ansalatina/notizie/rubriche/mundo/20110220193335221468.html The next next day it was reported that [[AMISOM]] troops destroyed a large complex of [[al-Shabaab]] trenches, and killed six [[al-Shabaab]] commanders in [[Mogadishu]]. Two AMISOM troops were [[Killed in action|KIA]].http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Press_Releases_32/AMISOM_Smashes_Extremist_s_Urban_Trench_System.shtml [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]] forces then advanced northwest into the Hodan district of Mogadishu. Resulting in that on February 23rd several strategic places were captured. This includes the former Defense Ministry that [[al-Shabaab]] have used as a base and where they launched the attacks from during the [[Battle_of_Mogadishu_(2010â2011)#August:_Ramadan_Offensive|Ramadan Offensive]]. Warshadda Aanaha (former Milk Factory) and sections of Industrial Road were also captured.http://www.allheadlinenews.com/briefs/articles/90036062http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jinDBlMmEMAPYqDhKKMqaEYADcKg?docId=CNG.97fd7d31409a22b937a0af220188ab56.3e1 At least 86 Somali soldiers, 8 AU soldiers, 70 [[al-Shabaab]] fighters and 45 civilians were killed during the battles.http://www.presstv.ir/detail/166668.htmlhttp://www.presstv.ir/detail/166624.htmlhttp://www.presstv.ir/detail/166889.htmlhttp://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j_DIYteM3AuBBiDfSgs8eHeJTT8A?docId=CNG.9fa1ad68e35f7997bfe4b91388f9a522.b61 A major explosion occurred on {{date|February 21st}} when a suicide car bomb exploded at a police post in the Hamar jajab district of [[Mogadishu]]. At least 20 people were killed, including [[TFG]] policemen and a woman.http://www.garoweonline.com/artman2/publish/Somalia_27/Suicide_car_bomb_killed_20_people_in_Mogadishu.shtml During February 25th [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]] forces took over [[Mogadishu]] junction Florence (Hararyale), Ged Jeâel in the street of Wadnahahttp://shabelle.net/article.php?id=3921 and advanced to around 500 meters from [[Bakaara Market]]. Another trench system used by [[al-Shabaab]] was discovered and destroyed.http://www.newvision.co.ug/D/8/13/747463 In February, over 50 AMISOM soldiers were killed by the insurgents.http://allafrica.com/stories/201103060001.htmlM As the offensive continued it was reported on March 5th that, up to 53 AMISOM may have died in the clashes. Of those, 43 Burundian and 10 Ugandan.{{cite news| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12650263 | work=BBC News | title=Somalia's al-Shabab 'holds 18 Burundian bodies' | date=March 4, 2011}} [[Burundi]] announced on March 12th that they had deployed 1,000 extra soldiers to [[AMISOM]] over a two day period. Bringing the total [[Burundi]] contribution up to 4,400 soldiers. On March 16th [[Abdikadir Yusuf Aar]] a.k.a. [[Abdikadir Yusuf Aar|Sheikh Qalbi]] a senior al-Shabaab official serving as the groups leader in Juba and Gedo region was killed in Mogadishu.{{cite news |url=http://sunatimes.com/view.php?id=914 |title=Burundi sends 1,000 extra AU troops to Somalia |author=Aweys Mohamed |work=Suna Times |date=March 19, 2011|accessdate=March 19, 2011}}{{cite news |url=http://www.waltainfo.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=25858&Itemid=47 |title=TFG forces make additional gains and strength |author= |work=Walta Info |date=March 26, 2011|accessdate=March 26, 2011}} ====May - June: [[Bakaara market]] offensive==== [[Bakaara market]] has for several years been one of the main strong holds and sources of income (together with the port in [[Kismayo]]) for [[al-Shabaab]]. The market has been used for launching attacks and for shooting mortars towards [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]] controlled areas of [[Mogadishu]]. It has been hard to target [[al-Shabaab]] hiding within the market as it's the largest in [[Somalia]] and packed with civilians. On May 12th [[TFG]], [[AMISOM]] and [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] launched an offensive towards [[Bakaara market]]. http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=6616 AU peacekeepers win territory from Somali rebels http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/May/blast_in_somalia_kills_5_pro_gov_t_troops.aspx Blast in Somalia kills 5 pro-gov't troops The goal of the offensive was to take control of [[Bakaara market]] located in the Hawl Wadag district of [[Mogadishu]]. It was part of a major offensive going on in several places in [[Somalia]] to take control of the areas under [[al-Shabaab]] control. Two days into the battle on May 14th the [[al-Shabaab]] commander of [[Bakaara market]] Abdifatah Mahamed was killed together with his intelligence officer Abdiwahab Sheik Dole.http://www.bar-kulan.com/2011/05/14/amisom-gains-ground-in-mogadishu/ AMISOM gains ground in Mogadishu On May 15th heavy fighting occurred when more than 35 people were killed in the fighting,http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/May/35_killed_in_mogadishu_clashes.aspx 35 killed in Mogadishu clashes including [[al-Shabaab]] commander of Hawlwadag destrict Ali Burhan "Ayatuulah".http://hornofafrica-abdikarim.blogspot.com/2011/05/amisom-takes-more-towns-in-somalia.html After four days of fighting [[TFG]], [[AMISOM]] and [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] forces had advanced around 500 meters towards the market. The front line was on May 16th around 500 - 700 meters north and west of the marked and 200 meters south of it. The areas sized from [[al-Shabaab]] included a former Sufi shrine that [[al-Shabaab]] used as a military base. In an attack on May 16th, 6 [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] soldiers were killed in a mortar attack and 17 injured.[http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=6614 6 pro-government fighters killed, 17 hurt in Mogadishu mortar attack] Heavy shelling hit the [[Bakaara Market]] on May 14th, resulting in at least 14 civilian deaths. Most of the civilians killed were women doing their shopping, one child was also among those killed.[http://www.kulmiyenews.com/?nid=1884 Somalia shelling kills 14 civilians at market] Shelling continued on May 20th and in Saraha Boliska in the Wadajir district, 3 people were killed in another shelling incident and 6 were injured. Mortars also hit the Bulahubey neighborhood, injuring 2 people.[http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=6768 Three killed in Mogadishu artillery shelling] A major breakthrough happened on May 22nd when most of the marked roads, including the Wadnaha road (National road) fell into the hands of [[TFG]] and [[AMISOM]].http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=6834 During the fighting, 2 civilians, 4 [[AMISOM]] soldiers and 22 [[al-Shabaab]] fighters were killed.http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/May/au_somali_forces_advance_onto_rebel_stronghold.aspx [http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/819/Fighting_Rages_in_Mogadishu_for_Bakara Al-Shabaab counter-attack in Mogadishu] [[al-Shabaab]] lost one of their top leaders in [[Mogadishu]]. Before being killed Abu Hubeyda was coordinating the [[al-Shabaab]] attacks from [[Bakaara market]]. As the [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]] forces advanced they captured the famous Red Mosque on May 23rd.http://www.hiiraan.com/news2/2011/may/government_troops_advance_to_southern_edge_of_bakara_market.aspx In an attempt on May 25th to open a second front and relief the some of the pressure from [[Bakaara market]], around 300 [[al-Shabaab]] fighters attacked [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]] bases in Bondere, Shingani and Scibis. At least 5 [[al-Shabaab]] fighters were killed.http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/836/Al-Shabaab_Counter-Attacks_in_Mogadishu?PHPSESSID=2e77f5622a677d4762e78b562bf2e0d7 Fighting continued the next night and at least 1 person was killed.http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7004 Due to the tense situation in [[Bakaara market]] merchants started to evacuate the market. Some of the shop keepers re-opened in [[TFG]] controlled parts of [[Mogadishu]].http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=6971 During the offensive several key places were captured by [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]]. They include the Red mosque, Wadnaha road (National road), Sheikh Ali Suffi mosque, African Village and "Tarabunka" (old parade ground).http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/856/President_Sharif_Tours_Frontlines_in_Mogadishu?PHPSESSID=9ea3b4e7763441ae8cbd67bed1c85266 Around 15 vehicles carrying foreign [[al-Shabaab]] fighters (of [[African]] origin and one truck of [[Demographics of Pakistan|Pakistani]] and [[Yemen]]ite) left Abdul Aziz district in [[Mogadishu]] heading to [[Afgoye]] on 30th May. At the same time [[al-Shabaab]] deployed fighters from [[Shabeellaha Hoose|Lower Shabelle]] and [[Bay, Somalia|Bay]] region to the front line in [[Bakaara market]] in an attempt to put an halt to the offensive made by [[AMISOM]] and [[TFG]].http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/871/Al-Shabaab_Shuffles_Fighters_in_Mogadishu?PHPSESSID=816f8288790a02af764151f471fd13fc At 16.45 hours [[al-Shabaab]] insurgence disguised as [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers driving a white mini van opened fire at [[AMISOM]] and [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] fighters at the "Dabka" base. The insurgence objective was the [[Ugandan]] [[AMISOM]] soldiers stationed in Maka Al-Mukarama. Due to a mistake the insurgence attacked the building next to the one holding [[AMISOM]] soldiers, and instead attacked the one holding [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] fighters. The area was heavy guarded and 3 of the [[al-Shabaab]] insurgence was killed in the firefight while 2 exploded (suicide bombers) killing several civilians on the Maka Al-Mukarama road. Then the rest of the insurgence (3) ran towards the Liberian village, where [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers were stationed. 2 [[AMISOM]] soldiers and 6 insurgence was killed in the attack. While 3 [[AMISOM]] soldiers and 6 [[Ahlu Sunna Waljama'a]] fighters was injured.[http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/865/Attack_on_ASWJAMISOM_Kills_Six_Wounds_Six Attack on ASWJ/AMISOM Kills Six, Wounds Six][http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/May/two_au_soldiers_killed_in_somalia_attack.aspx Two AU soldiers killed in Somalia attack]http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7082 One of the [[al-Shabaab]] suicide bomber killed during the attack was Abdullahi Ahmed, a [[Somali people|Somali]]/[[United States|American]] from [[Minneapolis]], [[USA]].http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/militants_somalia_suicide_bomber_from_minnesota.aspx [[al-Shabaab]] launched hit and run attacks on [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] bases at Warshadaha street in the early morning of 2nd June. At least 2 people was killed and 3 injured in the fighting that erupted.http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7132 Around 17 civilians were killed and 46 injured in the fighting that continued at Wadnaha Road, former Ministry of Defense and Hodan district.http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7152 Most of the casualties occurred when artillery fire hit a bus station. [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] continued their advance an penetrated deep into [[al-Shabaab]] trenches. [http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/17_die_in_clashes_at_mogadishu.aspx 17 die in clashes at Mogadishu ] The result of the fighting was that [[AMISOM]] ([[Burundi]] troops) and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] gained full control over Taranbunka road witch leads from Km 4 to the Industrial road as well as western access to [[Bakaara market]].http://sunatimes.com/view.php?id=1089 Friday 3rd June was a calm day in [[Mogadishu]]. [[AMISOM]] troops moved out of some of its key bases in the city, and moved forward to the newly established bases closer to [[Bakara market]] in African V illage and on Wadnaha road (National road). [[Somali Police Force]] will be tasked with the security in the rear ares where [[AMISOM]] pulled out.http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/889/AU_Moves_Troops_Tanks_to_Frontlines_?PHPSESSID=b33fed23cc71f39bdc804cc5bf448652http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7194 After using the Friday to prepare, [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] attacked [[al-Shabaab]] in the northeastern parts of [[Mogadishu]] on Saturday. [[AMISOM]] were advancing with tanks towards [[al-Shabaab]] positions. The whole district of Bondere (including the former embassies of [[Italy]] and [[Syria]]), Siinay Village in Wardhigley district and Afarta Jardiino in Yaqshid district and Damanyo military camp (Shirkole Ofshiale) were captured by [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]]. At least 15 people was killed (including 1 [[Ugandan]] soldier) and 30 injured. It is believed that the majority of the injured were civilians.http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7220http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/894/New_Mogadishu_Fighting_Pushes_North?PHPSESSID=9ea4b46bae71af6ff6e8e02ed557ffddhttp://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/amisom_says_captures_key_somali_district_from_rebels.aspxhttp://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7223http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/somalia_govt_amisom_take_over_al_shabaab_supply_routes.aspx The commander of the [[Ugandan]] 23rd Battalion, [[Lieutenant Colonel]] Patrick Tibihwa and 3 other [[Ugandan]] soldiers were killed on Saturday, 4th June. The [[Lieutenant Colonel]] is the highest ranking [[Ugandan]] officer killed in [[Somalia]]. He was killed by a stray bullet in Bondere district of [[Mogadishu]]. The 3 others were hit by mortars in the same district.[http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/ugandan_colonel_killed_in_somalia.aspx Ugandan Colonel killed in Somalia ]http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/909/Senior_Ugandan_Peacekeeper_Killed?PHPSESSID=eb276fb68e035dc585f9f08665f9343ehttp://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7293 Fighting continued on Sunday 5th June. Suqa Holaha, Jungal, Siisii and Fagah neighborhood was hit by several artillery shells. 8 civilians were killed and 15 injured. http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7233http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/mogadishu_s_sunday_of_more_death_and_destruction_fighting_makes_the_north_bloody.aspx [[Somali Police Force]] took over the security of Km 4, Guriga Shaqalaha, Isgoyska Dabka and Makka Almukara road on 6th June. This happened after [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] moved their forces to the front line in [[Mogadishu]].http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/912/Somali_Police_Take_Over_AMISOM_Bases Mortars hit the neighborhoods near the sea resort in Karan district. Around 10 civilian people was killed and residents started to evacuate the district in fear for more shelling.[http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7264 Ten killed in Mogadishu artillery barrages] 2 civilians were killed and 1 injured on 7th June, when [[al-Shabaab]] insurgence opened fire at [[khat]] traders in Almada area of [[Mogadishu]].http://sunatimes.com/view.php?id=1095 The head of [[Very Important Person|VIP]] section at [[Aden Adde International Airport]] Omar Abdulle Mohamed a.k.a Omar Qaldaan was [[Assassination|assasinated]] on 8th June. When he left a mosque in Dharkeynley district of [[Mogadishu]] a man dressed in the uniform of [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] approached him. When he noticed the man he then tried to escape but was shot in the head and died instantly. Since being appointed head of [[Very Important Person|VIP]] section at [[Aden Adde International Airport]] earlier this year he had received several death threats. [[al-Shabaab]] is the prime suspect after the [[Assassination]]. http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/919/Airport_Official_Assassinated_in_Mogadishu [[File:Fazul Abdullah Mohammed.jpg|thumb|3150px|[[al-Shabaab]] commander [[Fazul Abdullah Mohammed]].]] The top [[al-Shabaab]] commander [[Fazul Abdullah Mohammed]] and a Kenyan extremist Musa Hussein (a.k.a. Musa Sambayo), were driving in a car carrying $40,000 in [[United States Dollars]], as well as medicine, telephones, laptops and a [[South African passport]] in the [[Afgooye]] corridor, northwest of [[Mogadishu]] on June 8, 2011. Musa Hussein was known to Mohammed as Abdullahi Dere and is believed to have been involved in funding operations for [[al-Shabaab]].{{cite news |title=Kenyan-Somali Jihadist Killed With Fazul |url=http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/946/Kenyan-Somali_Jihadist_Killed_With_Fazul?PHPSESSID=d53d6324eb5fd8c973848c8fd87b6cf0 |newspaper=SomaliaReport.com |date=June 13, 2011 |accessdate=June 13, 2011}} They had been driving from [[Jubbada Hoose]] with destination [[Mogadishu]]. There they were to meet another [[al-Shabaab]] commander. As the front line was changing daily in [[Mogadishu]] they took took a wrong turn or got lost resulting in they entered Sarkuusta area in the outskirt of [[Mogadishu]] that [[TFG]]/[[AMISOM]] controlled.{{cite news |title='Fight at Mogadishu Checkpoint Kills 4 ' |url=http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1283/Fight_at_Mogadishu_Checkpoint_Kills_4?PHPSESSID=93e91e42edc2fbccb4792ea4d0e35139 |newspaper=Somalia Report |date=August 5, 2011 |accessdate=August 5, 2011}} At 2:00 A.M. they failed to stop at a [[security checkpoint]] managed by the [[Military of Somalia|Somalian military (SNA)]]. The [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] opened fire on the car, killing both Fazul Abdullah Mohammed and his accomplice.{{cite news |title='US Africa embassy bomber Fazul Abdullah Mohammed dead' |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-13737942 |newspaper=BBC News |date=June 11, 2011 |accessdate=June 12, 2011}} A suicide attack occurred at the [[Mogadishu]] port on 9th June. 2 [[al-Shabaab]] insurgence passed a check point at the port blended with other traders. Then they climbed over the fence and proceeded to the [[AMISOM]] base at the 4th store in the port. There they opened fire. One of the insurgence were shot and killed before being able to detonate the charge. The second insurgence detonated and killed 1 civilian. 3 [[AMISOM]] soldiers were injured in the attack.http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=7394http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/926/Suicide_Bombers_Attack_Mogadishu_Port One of the suicide bombers was later identified as 27 years old Farah Mohamed Beledi from [[Minnesota]], [[USA]].http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Jun/fbi_minnesota_man_was_suicide_bomber_in_somalia.aspx On 10 June, the Interior Minister [[Abdi Shakur Sheikh Hassan]] was killed by a bomb at his home in Soobe near Km 4 in [[Mogadishu]]. [[Somali Police Force]] claim he was killed when his niece from abroad Haboon Abdulkadir Hersi Qaaf acted as a suicide bomber. She was found dead at the scene, while the minister was taken to [[Banadir Hospital]] where he later was pronounced dead from the injuries sustained from the bomb.http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/936/Blast_Kills_Interior_Ministerhttp://sunatimes.com/view.php?id=1108 [[al-Shabaab]] however claimed responsibility for the attack and claim the bomb that detonated was planted under the ministers bed in his home.{{cite news| url=http://af.reuters.com/article/topNews/idAFJOE75A00320110611 | work=Reuters | title=Al Shabaab rebels claim killing of Somalia minister | date=June 11, 2011}}http://blog.american.com/2011/06/suicide-attacks-a-reminder-of-terrorists%E2%80%99-strength-in-somalia/ In beginning of June there was a political crises between President [[Sharif Sheikh Ahmed|Sheikh Sharif Sheikh Ahmed]] and the Speaker of Parliament [[Sharif Hassan Sheikh Aden]] with ended with the "Kampala accord" on 9th June.[http://www.washingtonpost.com/world/africa/somali-leaders-agree-to-postpone-elections-by-a-year-to-fix-security-and-political-issues/2011/06/09/AGXEd7MH_story.html Somali leaders agree to postpone elections by a year to fix security and political issues] During this time the offensive seem to have halted as the market has been beseiged from three sides. [[al-Shabaab]] leaders [[Sheikh Mukhtar Robow]] and [[Hassan Dahir Aweys]] are believed to have fled to [[Bakool]] region of [[Somalia]].Odowa, Mohamed [http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1303/Al-Shabaab_Quits_Mogadishu "Al-Shabaab Quits Mogadishu"] ''SomaliaReport'', August 6, 2011, accessed August 6, 2011[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14430283 "Somalia's al-Shabab rebels leave Mogadishu"] ''BBC News'', August 6, 2011, accessed August 6, 2011 On the morning of Saturday 6 [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[AMISOM]] were in control of most of the areas abandoned by [[al-Shabaab]] including [[Bakaara market]], [[Mogadiscio Stadium]] and the avenues Sodonka and Warshadaha.Haji, Mohamed [http://hiiraan.com/news2/2011/Aug/al_shabab_lost_strategic_frontlines_pulling_out_of_mogadishu.aspx "Al-Shabab Lost Strategic Frontlines Pulling Out Of Mogadishu"] ''Hiiraan Online'', August 6, 2011, accessed August 6, 2011 That same day, President [[Sharif Sheikh Ahmed]] said that [[al-Shabaab]] had been completely expelled from [[Mogadishu]].{{cite news|url=http://www.ansa.it/ansalatina/notizie/rubriche/mundo/20110806162935300563.html|title=MOGADISCIO "FUE LIBERADA", SEGUN PRESIDENTE SOMALI|publisher=[[Agenzia Nazionale Stampa Associata|ANSA]]|date=6 Aug 2011}} [[al-Shabaab]] militants attacked [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] army bases in Dayniile district. Nine people was killed and 13 were injured in the attack. The following day [[al-Shabaab]] launched new attacks on [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] in Yaqshid district. Two [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers where killed and two other injured. Later that day a car full of explosives blew up in the outskirts of [[Mogadishu]] leaving 14 people dead and 20 injured. On August 9th [[al-Shabaab]] attacked [[AMISOM]] bases in Abdiaziz district. Dour were killed and five injured.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1516/TFG_and_AMISOM_Battle_Al-Shabaab_in_Mogadishu|title=TFG and AMISOM Battle Al-Shabaab in Mogadishu|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=9 September 2011}} On August 14, al-Shabaab declared they would switch from conventional tactics to hit and run attacks and vowed to continue such attacks, claiming they inflicted more casualties on AMISOM that way.{{cite news|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201108150106.html|title=Somalia: Al Shabaab Declares It Began Hit And Run Attacks|publisher=AllAfrica.com|date=14 Aug 2011}} The following day [[al-Shabaab]] claimed the tactic to be successful and to have killed one [[AMISOM]] soldier from [[Uganda]].{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1367/Al-Shabaab_Claims_New_Tactics_Successful|title=Al-Shabaab Claims New Tactics Successful|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=15 August 2011}} [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] continued to advance in [[Mogadishu]], and took control over Hotel Ramadan, Hotel Kaah, Ex-mali TV center, Towfik junction, Towfik market, Ahmed Gurey School and Jungle on August 16. They encountered some resistance from [[al-Shabaab]] fighters, but they were quickly overrun.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1376/Pro-Government_Forces_Advance_in_Mogadishu|title=Pro-Government Forces Advance in Mogadishu|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=16 August 2011}} Three employees (a nurse, a logistic officer and a driver) of Daynile Hospital in [[Mogadishu]] were kidnapped by [[al-Shabaab]] in the Huriwa district on 17 August.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1376/Pro-Government_Forces_Advance_in_Mogadishu|title=Arrests, Surrender and Defiance|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=17 August 2011}} Seven people and 15 were injured in fighting between [[AMISOM]]/[[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[al-Shabaab]]. At least three people were killed and six injured when [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] clashed in Dharkenly district of [[Mogadishu]] on 20 August. The fighting started after disagreement on the taxation at a check-point and looting of aid supplies.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1406/Fighting_Among_TFG_Soldiers_Kills_3|title=Fighting Among TFG Soldiers Kills 3|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=20 August 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=9944|title=One soldier dies as Somali forces clash in Mogadishu; aid food looted|publisher=Shabelle Media Network|date=20 August 2011}} [[Fuad Mohamed Qalaf]] spoke at a mosque in Eelasha-Biyaha district of [[Mogadishu]] on 21 August. He announced that [[al-Shabaab]] would assassinate those who support [[TFG]] and [[civilian]]s would not be spared.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1413/Al-Shabaab_Warns_Civilians_Over_Defeat|title=Al-Shabaab Warns Civilians Over Defeat|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=21 August 2011}} The same day six civilians were injured in a grenade attack aimed at a [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] foot patrol at the Dabakayo-Madow village in the Dharkenyley district. [[al-Shabaab]] is the prime suspected as the bomber escaped from the scene.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1416/Grenade_Aimed_at_TFG_Soldiers_Hits_Kids?PHPSESSID=288a947a7ad3f65b5eba082847a5f3c2|title=Grenade Aimed at TFG Soldiers Hits Kids|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=21 August 2011}} Three civilians were injured when [[al-Shabaab]] attacked a [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] base in Dharkinley district with hand granades. [[al-Shabaab]] attacked [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] bases in Yaqshid district on 23rd August. Three people were killed and the injured. The following day the [[Somali Police Force]] arrested three men carrying explosives in Dharkinley district. On 27th August, [[al-Shabaab]] attacked [[AMISOM]] and [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] on several locations in [[Mogadishu]]. Ten people was killed and 15 injured. Soldiers from [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] foiled a suicide attack at KM4 captureing a car full of explosives. 900 [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers graduated from Bihanga Military training School in Bihanga, [[Uganda]] on 31 August.{{cite news|url=http://www.bar-kulan.com/2011/09/02/900-newly-trained-somali-soldiers-dispatched-from-ugandan-military-school/|title=900 newly trained Somali soldiers dispatched from Ugandan military school|publisher=Bar-Kulan|date=2 September 2011}} ====September==== On September 2, the 39-year-old Malaysian [[camera operator]] [[Noramfaizul Mohd Nor]], who was working for [[Malaysia]]'s national [[Bernama TV]], was shot and killed and fellow [[journalist]] and camera operator Aji Saregar Mazlan from [[TV3 (Malaysia)]] was wounded. The incident happened on Shakhala road, at the Kilometer Four intersection. It was four [[AMISOM]] soldiers from [[Burundi]] that opened fire on their vehicle, which was being escorted by soldiers from [[Military of Somalia|SNA]].{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1497/Malaysian_Journalist_Killed_in_Mogadishu|title=Malaysian Journalist Killed in Mogadishu|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=2 September 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-14771821|title=Journalist killed in shooting attack in Somali capital|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=2 September 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=11266|title=Troops in Somalia killed journalist, report says|publisher=[[Associated Press|AP]]|date=26 September 2011}} In August [[TFG]] decided to remove all checkpoints in and around [[Mogadishu]].{{cite news|url=http://www.bar-kulan.com/2011/08/29/a-sigh-of-relief-as-officials-remove-a-checkpoint-in-hamarweyne-district/|title=A sigh of relief as officials remove a checkpoint in Hamarweyne district|publisher=Bar-kulan|date=29 August 2011}} Fighting broke out when soldiers of [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] were to remove a checkpoint in Wadajir district on 2 September. Shortly after the fighting started soldiers from [[AMISOM]] arrived and restored order. The checkpoint were run by militia loyal to Ahmed Da'i, the districk commissioner of Wadajir. Four people including two [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers where killed and six was wounded.{{cite news|url=http://www.somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1501/4_Killed_in_Military_Clashes_in_Mogadishu|title=4 Killed in Military Clashes in Mogadishu|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=2 September 2011}} [[al-Shabaab]] gunmen attacked [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] soldiers on patrol in Wadajir district on 4 September. At least 13 people was killed in the attack that lasted for two hours.{{cite news|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/197296.html|title=13 die in battle for Mogadishu|publisher=[[Press TV]]|date=4 September 2011}} [[al-Shabaab]] attacked [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[AMISOM]] bases in the former defense ministry, Gulwadayaasha military camp, Jale Siyad faculty and Ex-control [[Afgoye]] junction on 9th September. Three people were killed and five sustained injuries. On September 8, a soldier from [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] started to shoot at [[Internally displaced person|IDP]]s in the Waberi district. Six civilians were killed and three people was injured. The soldier was arrested at the scene.{{cite news|url=http://shabelle.net/article.php?id=10553|title=Somali soldier kills six civilians in Mogadishu shooting spree|publisher=Shabelle Media Network|date=8 September 2011}} ====October==== On october 20th Soldiers from [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[AMISOM]] entered Daynile, the last district in [[Mogadishu]] that was under the control of [[al-Shabaab]]. The offensive started well with little resistance. As they advanced into the Daynile district [[al-Shabaab]] sealed off their retreat route and opened fire with rifles, belt-fed machine guns and rocket-propelled grenades. A Burundian peacekeeper, Cpl. Arcade Arakaza later said: -''It was a classic envelope trap, with the Shabab drawing the peacekeepers deeper into their lair, sealing off the escape routes and then closing in from all sides.''{{cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/25/world/africa/africa-forces-surprise-many-with-success-in-subduing-somalia.html?_r=1&pagewanted=all|title=African Union Force Makes Strides Inside Somalia|publisher=[[The New York Times]]|date=24 November 2011|first=Jeffrey|last=Gettleman}} [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[AMISOM]] managed to fight back and capture the Daynile police station. In the evening [[al-Shabaab]] reinforced with fighters from [[Lower Shabelle]], [[Bay, Somalia|Bay]] and [[Bakool]] launched a counter-attack re-captured the strategic important Daynile police station. The following day [[AMISOM]] sent reinforcements to the area and heavy fighting continued.{{cite news|url=http://somaliareport.com/index.php/post/1802/Al-Shabaab_Fights_for_Survival|title=Al-Shabaab Fights for Survival|publisher=SomaliaReport|date=21 October 2011}} When the battle was over more than 70 soldier from [[AMISOM]] (mostly [[Burundi]]) had been killed and the Daynile district had fallen in the hands of [[Military of Somalia|SNA]] and [[AMISOM]]. At least 60 of the [[AMISOM]] soldiers killed in the ambush were put on display by [[al-Shabaab]]s [[spokesperson]] [[Ali Mohamud Rage]] in the Alamada area, 18 km outside [[Mogadishu]].{{cite news|url=http://www.nrk.no/nyheter/verden/1.7842592|title=Viste fram 70 lik til pressen|publisher=[[NRK]]|date=20 October 2011}}{{cite news|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/Mogadishu-massacre-70-AU-troops-killed-20111020|title=Mogadishu massacre - 70 AU troops killed|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse|AFP]]|date=20 October 2011}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} {{coord missing|Somalia}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Battle Of Mogadishu (2010)}} [[Category:Conflicts in 2010]] [[Category:Conflicts in 2011]] [[Category:War in Somalia (2009â)]] [[Category:History of Mogadishu]] [[Category:Battles involving Somalia]] [[Category:Somali Civil War]] [[ar:ÙØ¹Ø±ÙØ© ÙÙØ¯ÙØ´Ù (2010â2011)]] [[de:Gefechte in Mogadischu 2010/2011]] [[pl:Bitwa w Mogadiszu (2010-2011)]]
